author: Deleted User
content: When looking at the "Event stream" sheet I wonder if there should be a `type` field in the `data` Json objects in order to distinguish the event the data corresponds to - currently one would have to check the fields in the object

author: jgm
content: The plan is to have a "type" field as a sibling of data in the return object.

author: jgm
content: That way the data is event-specific and fits with the existing API (and we don't trip up if some other data object has a type field)

author: mpetrunic
content:
> The plan is to have a "type" field as a sibling of data in the return object.
<@!144468805697929216> why not use specified type field for sse, because data field in sse need to be json stringiffied so you would need to parse every data string to find out type?

author: jgm
content: Are we definitely using SSE as our mechanism?  Wasn't sure if that was decided yet

author: jgm
content: If not, there's no guarantee we'll have an out-of-band source like event type we can work with.  Putting it all in a single JSON object makes it method-independent

author: mpetrunic
content:
> Are we definitely using SSE as our mechanism?  Wasn't sure if that was decided yet
<@!144468805697929216> hope so. What are other alternatives except for websockets?

author: jgm
content:
Had a quick look.  Regarding the specific points you raised in the PR:

   - doesn't make a lot of difference if we use the Fork object in fork schedule (I don't think the call will use previous_version, but using a standard object is a good thing); may as well stick with Fork 
  - chain ID for deposit contract is useful in a couple of situations.  First, it allows ease of use for testnets.  Second, if there is ever a contentious hard fork on Ethererum 1 we'll know which fork to follow
  - the general "configuration parameters" endpoint probably needs better definition.  Need to know how we're returning domains, for example (int, byte array, string?)

author: jgm
content:
> 
> <@!144468805697929216> hope so. What are other alternatives except for websockets?

websockets are the obvious alternative.  SSE seem to have some oddities in its standard, such as mandating reconnects, but its simplicity is appealing.

Only potential concern is that the data is restricted to UTF-8, but if we're passing mainly roots (attestations being the exception) that shouldn't matter.
